# Results

## Gender frequencies
```{r rate, echo=F}
# data[row,col]
data$undergrad_ratio <- data$undergrad_male / data$undergrad_female
data$graduate_ratio <- data$graduate_male / data$graduate_female
data$total_ratio <- data$total_male / data$total_female

## Subsetting
#data <- data[which(data$total > 100), c("Department", "undergrad_ratio",  "graduate_ratio", "total_ratio")]
data <- data[order(data$total_ratio, decreasing = T),c(1, grep("ratio", names(data)))]
kable(head(data),row.names = F, caption = "Most men")

data <- data[order(data$total_ratio, decreasing = F),c(1, grep("ratio", names(data)))]
kable(head(data), row.names = F, caption = "Most women")
```

## Clustering
For cluster analysis it is important to remember that 
* We should use continous variables 
* We should standardise data if types or ranges are different

```{r clustering, echo = FALSE, fig.width=12, fig.height=12}
#data <- data[which(data$total > 1000), c("Department", "undergrad_ratio",  "graduate_ratio", "total_ratio")]

## make matrix
m <- as.matrix(data[,2:ncol(data)])
rownames(m) <- data[,1]

## Calculate the distances
mydist <- dist(m)
hc <- hclust(mydist)
plot(hc, cex = 0.8)
```
